Two bands, whose combined

Chinese lanterns surrounding the

finest enjoyable dance music.
Bob Holmar, chairman of

''The H-Club has made a special effort to satisfy everyone

bands of different musical specialties."

dance for fear of not hearing the
style which he prefers. Having
two bands will also insure an
uninterrupted supply of music.
There will be four hours of music
with no breaks."
Tickets for the dance may be
purchased at the Student Shop,
in Levering Hall, in the dormitory cafeteria, or from any
H-Club member. Prices for the
tickets are $2.50 in advance, but
will be $3.00 at the door. Tables
may be reserved at the Student
Shop.
Saturday night's weather forecast is for a beautiful balmy
night, ideal for romancing under
the stars and full moon at the
fabulous Starlighter. Should our
friendly forecaster be wrong,
however, a pleasant evening has
been assured. The dance will be
held at the gym, which will be
completely decorated.

A Last Request
Before retiring for the year from the editorial lists,
we feel compelled once more to consider the nature of
the Great Change which seems to have overcome Hopkins in the last twelve months. The growing concern
with undergraduate affairs which has been manifested
by the adult members of our community seems to
portend some radical shifts in policy in the future.
The latest expression of interest in reform has come
from the Alumni Association in the form of an address
to the Student Council on the subject of student behavior in the stands at athletic events.
This active participation in what has heretofore
been the exclusive concern of the students themselves
might, it seems, be the beginning of the end for the
long cherished view of the Hopkins undergraduate as a
mature being, responsible individual capable of acting
independently witihn his sphere. The administration,
through the Committee on Undergraduate Affairs has
taken a long, hard look at its charges and apparently
does not like what it sees; from a community of budding
scholars we have, it would appear, degenerated into an
immature rabble, unfit to be trusted with the maintenance of our own affairs.
While Hopkins is hard on its undergraduates in
many respects, one of the chief benefits which it grants
them has been the opportunity to develop without interference from the adult world they are preparing to
join. To gain better orientation, more spirit, a better
public image etc. at the expense of this freedom would
defeat the purpose of an education at the Homewood.
Hopkins has existed in the past under an essentially
unrestricted system. When Hopkins' worst faults are
corrected, we sincerely hope it will he able to return
to a state of freedom from outside interference.

Among The Deepening Shades
As the ineluctable cycling of the heavenly spheres
whirls us once more toward the yawning abyss of exams,
we fold our editorial tent and stalk silently off into
the tall grass of summer. Watching Hopkins move into
another phase of its dusty journey westward, we can
4)n1y extend our heartfelt wishes that the Great Mediator
will grant us all a harmonious peace.
